thread.title: British Airways flight forced to abort landing to prevent crash with private jet
thread.title_full: British Airways flight forced to abort landing to prevent crash with private jet | Daily Mail Online

author: John Hutchinson for MailOnline
title: British Airways flight forced to abort landing to prevent crash with private jet
text:
832 shares 46
View
comments
A passenger plane was forced to take evasive action to avoid crashing into an incoming private jet.
The near-miss occurred at Geneva Airport when the British Airways flight was told to perform a 'go around' after a private jet entered the airspace at the same time.
Simultaneously, an Aer Lingus Airbus A320 was speeding down the runway ready to head out to Dublin, Ireland.
A BA flight that was scheduled to land at Geneva Airport had to perform a 'go around' due to a private jet entering the runway at the same time
However, the air traffic controller spotted the Cessna Citation jet entering the same runway, and he radioed the Aer Lingus captain, asking him to 'hold position.'
The BA Airbus was scheduled to land once the Aer Lingus plane had cleared the runway, yet this was told to 'go around' due to the private jet being in the airspace.
 Next Everything but the kitchen sink! Jaw-dropping photos show... Dramatic POV footage captures passengers' panic then relief... The animal kingdom as you've never seen it before:... The tiniest dentist in the world! Diver opens his mouth up... 832 shares The Irish Examiner reports that the air traffic controller told the BA flight pilot: 'Speedbird 726, go around, I repeat go around, traffic has interfered on the runway.'
The plane then aborted its scheduled landing.
A Cessna Citation aircraft came in to approach the runway at Geneva Airport causing two passenger jets to take evasive action (file photo, not actual jet)
The Aer Lingus captain, meanwhile, notified ground control that they just 'had enough room to take a right around the traffic.'
When the pilot of the Aer Lingus plane was asked if they were 'okay' he replied: 'Affirm, we had enough room to take a right around the traffic but luckily we were okay, yes.'
A spokesperson for Aer Lingus told MailOnline Travel: 'I can confirm that our aircraft was involved in an incident at Geneva, Friday, July 24.
'We have submitted necessary reports to the relevant authorities and are awaiting feedback. At all times our crew were compliant with procedures and air traffic instructions.'
Last night a spokeswoman for BA said: 'Our highly trained pilots ensured that the aircraft landed safely after they were asked to perform a standard procedure by air traffic controllers.'
